Key Arguments: The legislation threatens democratic rights by potentially leading to censorship.
ACMA could become a 'ministry of truth', deciding what is true or false.
The definitions in the bill are vague and subjective, leading to potential misuse.
The bill could deter digital platforms from operating in Australia due to heavy fines.
The exclusion of certain content types creates a double standard.
The concept of 'harm' is subjective and could be misused to suppress free speech.
Notable Quotes: Our democratic rights will be under threat, should this bill pass.
One rule for us, another rule for them is the impression this excluded content clause leaves. A very Un-Australian approach to governance.
Harm is inherently subjective. Science, by its very nature, is never settled.
At the end of the day, the so-called 'problem' of misinformation and disinformation is pure nonsense.
